Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän, I came down here to let you know we're set to reach the target Morganas within the hour.
Perfect. We're right on schedule.
It seems strange that we're changing our course so abruptly. I thought we were on our way to help our allies with repairs.
We've had to change plans, Theodor. This is more important.
Do you prefer attacking the Nixen, or helping your friends?

Fields.MenuText: Fighting the Morganas.
Helping others.
I don't know.

Fields.DialogueText: I think we should only be fighting if it's our last resort...
Our friends could certainly use our help as well.
Well, if we could do both, I guess that would be best.
We don't make the orders, Theodor. We just follow them.
*Sigh* I suppose you're right. I need to remember that we're fighting a war, here.
That's right. It's not all fun and games.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Did that last attack hit us hard?
I-I think we're going to be all right. The Morganas hit us with a surprise attack. I didn't think they were capable of that kind of force.

Fields.MenuText: We need to focus on not getting ambushed.
The Morganas are capable of anything.

Fields.DialogueText: I can see if I can put more staff on the lookout, or on the FuMO, if you'd like.
They're our greatest enemy, Captain... Capable of everything evil.
We're going to have to stop soon, unfortunately.
But if we stop, that means that the Nixen will catch up to us!
Based on their movements, it looks like they're going to surround us.
What are we going to do?
Just let me think for a little bit, Theodor.
Jawohl, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: We handled it pretty well, all things considered.

Fields.DialogueText: Even so, I'd rather they didn't do it again.
I can respect that.
Kapitän? I came here to apologize. I should have been more patient before.

Fields.MenuText: It's fine. No apologies needed.
I just needed a moment.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke. You're very kind.
Well, I'm glad you got your moment to yourself, Kapitän.
Well, if you want to talk, I am ready to listen.
Right. I say we go all in before things get any worse. We're going to take the Morganas down right here, right now.
It sounds risky - but I'm willing to try, Kapitän.
Okay. No time like the present.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I appreciate that. Apology accepted.

Fields.DialogueText: The weather gives us a chance to take out a carrier before they can rain hell on us, and I don't think we can afford to pass that up.
Are you ready for the next round, Theodor Riedel?
Well, I may as well be. There isn't much else we can do, is there?
Well, what would you do in this situation? Look at my map. The marks in red are where the Morganas are.
Where are we?
We're in blue.
You should probably use a color that doesn't remind us of sinking into the ocean.
Now's not the time for jokes, Theodor Riedel...
Es tut mir Leid. Right... now we see that fleet of Morganas is moving this way, so we should move away from them, right?
I propose we drive them collectively by moving with the Morganas.
That way we can all go toward one side? Genius!

Fields.MenuText: That's right, and we can use all the help we can get.
Well, I wouldn't call myself a genius...
This is a common strategy. You should know this!

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I'll make sure to fight to the best of my abilities, Kapitän.
You need to give yourself more credit. Without you, we would never have gotten this far.
It's not something that comes up often in my fairy tales, Kapitän!
Well, are you ready to take the offensive?
Jawohl!
@BATTLE
May I retract that statement?
Please.
We've managed to elude them.
The Morganas seem to be holding their position right now. We should keep moving before they attempt another attack.
I think that's a good idea, Kapitän. I don't want to needlessly get into any fights.

Fields.MenuText: Neither do I.
I'm doing what's best for the ship.
I'm always down for a fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that's good then. We should still keep ready, in case of a surprise offensive.
I understand, Kapitän. We need to look at our best interest in total.
I'm not sure if I'm nearly as prepared as you are, Captain...
We need to make sure the Morganas won't attack. Will you be able to check out the listening station for me?
Ja!
Great. Hopefully we won't see any trouble coming soon...
Um, Kapitän, I think you're going to want to see this...
Is it the Morganas?
I'm seeing reports of unknown objects swimming around us.
That seems... odd. Do we have any idea what they might be?
They could be whales. Or maybe... mermaids!

Fields.MenuText: Whales make more sense to me.
Mermaids? Relax, Theodor.
You might be right! MERMAIDS! Finally!

Fields.DialogueText: Whales are a good sign that we're away from the Morganas right now.
Hey, I'm just fooling around! What if there are really mermaids?
Kapitän, can we go search for them?
Let's go see outside, maybe we can get a glimpse of... whatever this is.
Huh? They've disappeared off of the FuMO.
Why?
Now something else has appeared on the FuMO. Ahh! It's the Morgana fleet!
@BATTLE
Still no sign of those mysterious creatures we saw, Kapitän.
It could have been anything out there...  I wonder if it was just a practical illusion.
I bet it was something mystical... Hmm, maybe I should write a story about it.
We should figure out how to defeat the Morganas first.
Oh, Kapitän, do you always have to think about work?

Fields.MenuText: It's what we're here for, Theodor.
It's not all I think about.
Well, I could use a break sometimes.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, ja. Can't we just relax for a little?
Hmm, I haven't seen you do anything but work.
Ja! Everyone needs a break now and then.
But it's impossible. We need to get ready for the next battle.
Oh, all right. Just let me pack up my things.
*CRASH*
Autsch. I fell.
Ouch - but no time to complain, the Morganas are back!
@BATTLE
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
What are you doing, Theodor?
Oh, just re-reading some old fairy tale stories that I like.
Can you tell me which one you're reading?
This one is called "Hänsel und Gretel." It's about a brother and a sister who wander in the woods. Do you know of it?

Fields.MenuText: I know this story well.
I'm familiar with it.
I don't know it at all.

Fields.DialogueText: I think it's really a classic. It reminds me of how innocence prevails over cruelty.
Ja, it's a pretty popular story. It's no surprise they keep making film versions.
You should really read it later! It has a magic candy house, and a witch, and so much more!
I'm assuming you've read it before.
Indeed. I've read all of the stories in Grimms Märchen before. I just like reading them over and over.
I guess one may learn a lot from old fables... But for now, we're going to have to sail off. So pack up that book, Theodor!
Aww, and I was just getting to the good part!
"Innocence?" Don't the kids end up burning the witch alive?
... Perhaps "cunning" is a better word.
It looks like there aren't any Morganas on our screens...
That's so strange. Usually the sea is swarming with them.
I know. Plus, it's foggy.

Fields.MenuText: We should proceed cautiously.
We should wait until the fog lifts.
We have nothing to fear.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree, Kapitän. You never know what's lurking there - friend or foe!
I agree, Kapitän. This fog certainly will impede any movement we try to make.
Nothing - except for Morganas, that is! I'm not scared. I'm just... cautious.
Well, between conventional sensors and Belle senses. So we have nothing to worry for now.
What the conventional sensors are broken?
Or are being interfered with. Yeah, I know, there's precedent. We just need to keep our eyes open and-
Kapitän! A dark shadow approaches through the fog!
How? How do they do that?
That's a question we will have to save for another time.
@BATTLE
That was a close one.
Phew! I'm feeling a little dizzy from that battle. All this noise - so loud!
Go sit down, Theodor. You may have a concussion from the cannons.
Why do these battles have to be so intense?

Fields.MenuText: It's always a race for whoever has the best technology.
We need to be able to fight this war with everything we've got.
I hate these cannons, too. We should go back to using swords like pirates.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. Just one day, we may be too overpowered and in over our heads. All the rumors you hear about experimenting with the Nixen's own weapons...
I've noticed. We have more armaments on this ship than what entire countries have!
If only we could make a peace pact with the Morganas. Though your idea may be more gruesome. Bläh!
We should go and attend to the ship now. Theodor, you need to lie down. Let me help you.
I've hit my head plenty of times, Kapitän. This is no different. *WHOOP!*
*CRASH*
Theodor!
Oh, my head...
Ah! Out there - it's more Morganas!
How do they keep getting so close?
@BATTLE
I don't know much, and I can't talk about what I do know.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Schon wieder! The Nixen evaded our sensors. Was stimmt nur nicht?
I don't know. Think it's worth bringing electricians in? Check the integrity of our detection systems? Maybe something got fried somewhere.
Don't blame the technology, Kapitän. These Morganas are quite crafty.

Fields.MenuText: I guess you're right.
Still doesn't explain anything.

Fields.DialogueText: Weil sie schwach sind, nutzen sie List.... we have to put an end to this.
Maybe the Morganas developed a new way to cloak their ships. Just a thought.
We're going to have to double the lookouts until we find out what's wrong with our toys.
Allow me to volunteer for the first shift, Kapitän.
It's a boring job.
Good thing I have a bunch of stories to read!
Yeah... don't forget the point of "looking out."
I'll do my best!

Fields.MenuText: True. But it's always worth double-checking the basics.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't disagree. But I think I would know if something was just broken.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Theodor! How come our guards noticed the Morganas before you did? I thought you were on guard.
Err, I may have not been paying attention.
I wasn't reading. I think I was just, uh, daydreaming.
Seriously?
I have a short attention span! I can't help it. If I'm staying still, my mind just wanders. Am I in trouble?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, you are.
No, you're fine.
It's really my fault.

Fields.DialogueText: I figured. I'll make up for it, I promise!
I swear, it won't happen again. Really.
Kapitän, you can't take the blame for something I did!
We're going to switch things up. You're not on lookout. I'm putting you out on patrol. That way you can walk around.
Jawohl! I'll start right now!
Good!
Uhh, Kapitän, there's weird stuff floating in the water!
Oooh, boy.
This better not be what I think it is...
It's food! Someone dropped food overboard.
This is very odd.
Look at that, it looks like they are forming a trail.
Yeah, that's not strange at all.
What should we do, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: We should follow it.
We should stay on course.
We should get that food!

Fields.DialogueText: I think it could lead to treasure! I sense an adventure!
Well, that's probably a good idea. I mean, it's just some waste in the sea.
Eww, soggy bread and meat, Kapitän?
I wonder how all that food got in the ocean.
Kapitän, hand me your Fernglas!
Here you go.
Out in the water! The Morganas! They must be following the trail too. Let's get them!
@BATTLE
So, the Morganas were pretty easy to find. Do you think they were along the trail for a reason?

Fields.MenuText: They were probably attracted to the food.
I wonder if they were trying to clean up the sea?
Who knows, the Morganas are mindless souls!

Fields.DialogueText: That food looked good, maybe we should have taken some.
Ja, except they didn't pick any of that trash up at all.
All they want to do is kill... those evil creatures!
Well, we did see Morganas this way... and it looks like the trail of bread follows along even farther.
I wonder how far it goes? Maybe we will be able to find out more about those Morganas if we follow it.
Well, I just hope it doesn't lead us into any danger.
Now that you mention it, I do recall a story that dealt with bread crumbs. But there's no way that has anything to do with this.
Let's follow it. I want to see where it leads. And if we see any Morganas along the way -
They won't know what hit them!
@BATTLE
So, you've heard of the Hänsel und Gretel story, right?
Yes.
In the story, Hänsel und Gretel leave a trail of breadcrumbs to find their way home. It ends up being their salvation.
Don't you think we're following along some kind of trail right now? The Morganas have been right along this pathway, too.
Yeah, that could be possible.
Do you think someone left this behind? If they did... are they good, or are they bad?

Fields.MenuText: I think an ally left them.
I think an enemy left them.
It's too early to tell.

Fields.DialogueText: We need to go out and help them, then!
Well, that explains why we see so many Nixen along the way.
You're right. We're going to find out one way or another.
So, shall we continue onward?
Hey, you're the Kapitän, not me!
@BATTLE
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Why do you think you like these stories so much, Theodor Riedel?
I like the idea of fantasy. It's a world that's better than our own.
In fantasy, they have problems, just like we do.
But every story has a lesson. It all has a point, a purpose.
I think I'm still trying to find my purpose, Kapitän. But I'm not at the end of the story yet.
Hopefully, it'll all wrap up, nice and clean.
Ja. I hope so too. Sorry if this bugged you, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: No, it didn't bug me.
Not at all. It's a good story. I'm invested.
Yeah, I'm a little bugged.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad. I just felt like I had to share something about myself.
Aww, Kapitän. That's sweet of you to say that.
Well, I'll leave you alone now.
I just hope the Morganas don't cut our stories short.
Do you still write stories about the crew?
Sometimes. I try to make up new stories as well. But overall, I like trying to make up these "happy endings" for everyone. Even you, Kapitän!

Fields.MenuText: Real life doesn't have endings like your stories.
I always like happy endings.
I feel that if it's not real, then why should it matter?

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but if I can imagine a better world, then maybe this one won't seem so bad.
I think that a good ending always satisfies a story. I hate when conflicts are left unresolved.
Of course it matters! It's either entertainment, or a social critique on our lives!
You seem to be very interested in the ideas of storytelling.
People have been telling stories for generations, Kapitän. It's how we share information, share lessons with each other.
I think the best part about stories is seeing how they sit with someone after they're being told.
Maybe if the Morganas heard a story, they'd learn to stop attacking us all the time.
Sehr witzig, Kapitän. Very funny.
@BATTLE
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Right. Once again, we didn't get a single blip on our screens until they were right on top of us. Theodor, are you-
Look at all the pretty lights!
We don't know what that means. It could be a Morgana, or it could be anything else...
Is it too late to rule out the mermaids?
A little bit, yeah.
I'm going to go look outside for a minute.
It's almost as if something is gathering underneath the ocean.
Come outside, Kapitän. You may want to see this.
What - what is this? All of the debris in the middle of the ocean.
Look... just like that food from earlier. It's following a trail. Should we?
Yes. Let's go.
Huh.
So the report has come in. It looks like some of our detection problems had something to do with this debris.
I'll wager that the Morgana fleet had something to do with this.
So it sounds like as we continue to follow on this trail, we'll be led right to the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, that's correct.
We don't know that for sure.
Or it could be anyone else.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope they don't see us coming...
That's right. But what if it's a trap, or something! I'm not worried...
Who else are our enemies? The Morganas are the ones we need to beat.
We're going to go along this trail again, either way.
I know it worked out well last time, but I have a strange, bad feeling about this.
What's wrong?
Well, last time it was easy, but this time it's not the same. There isn't food in the water. Instead, it looks like pieces of broken ships.
It's a little intimidating, I'll give you that much.
I just need to suck it up, Kapitän.
Once you do that, I see the Morganas out in the distance!
Mist. Already?
@BATTLE
This isn't so bad!
Are you listening to yourself? Look at the ship! It's a mess. The Morganas really did a number on us.

Fields.MenuText: Hey, we beat them, didn't we?
Oh, it's not so bad out here.
I have no idea what you mean.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, so in the long run, I guess we lucked out... less Morganas in the world.
I think some of your crew would greatly disagree with you.
Well, there are these things called Morganas. And they shoot at us. Sometimes, they shoot a lot.
It looks like the trail is thinning out.
Well, do you think we're getting to the end?
We have to push ahead. There's only one way to know.
*Sigh* I'm ready to relax. Maybe take a nap.
*BOOM*
Did we just get hit?
Nein! An assault was made, but it just missed us.
There's no one in sight...
They may be firing at distance, but they've got pretty good aim...
Figure out where the hell they are! We need to make our way through this next battle - and fast!
@BATTLE
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
We're in a bit of trouble.
(I knew this was a bad idea.)
What was that, Theodor Riedel?
Oh, nothing.
I think we should make a break while the Morganas retreat temporarily. But how...
May I make a suggestion, Kapitän?
Go right ahead.
The Morganas led a trail of desecration this way. But it's a trail of open water now that we've cleared a path. Can't we just follow the trail back out of range of the Morganas?

Fields.MenuText: I love the idea. Where did you get it from?
It's so crazy and simple that it just might work!
I guess it's our only option. Here goes nothing.

Fields.DialogueText: It's how Hänsel and Gretel escape the evil witch at the end of the story.
Sometimes, the simplest plans often work out the best.
I'm prepared to accept the consequences if anything goes wrong, Kapitän.
It looks like we have a clear path out of here! I'm calling backup to ensure we'll be prepared in case the Morganas catch up to us.
Aye, aye, Kapitän. It looks like those Morganas aren't too bright after all...
So, this plan of yours. It seems to be working well. We've gained some distance from the Morganas and have made recoveries.
That's a relief. I was worried we wouldn't be able to survive another barrage.
This idea of yours, it came from Hänsel and Gretel?
Ja. That's right, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: There seems to be some merit to fairy tales.
Wow, who knew!

Fields.DialogueText: They're all about life lessons for kids, for adults, for anyone!
Honestly, I wasn't even sure this plan was going to work. But it looks like we're safe, thanks to some ingenuity.
I'm glad you're by my side, Theodor Riedel. This was your brilliance.
Well, gee, Kapitän. Don't embarrass me like this!
Okay. You ready to go back in and work on the Morganas?
Can we just take on the Morganas at long range?
No offense, but their guns are probably better at distance than ours.
Then what are we waiting for?
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Let's leave that out when we report to Command.

Fields.DialogueText: Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
I've changed a lot thanks to reading these stories. I'm no longer just passive and simple.
I never thought of you that way.
Well, I used to never understand anything I was taught, like the world was this big, bad and mysterious place.
Well, when I read these tales, it's like I enter a world where I feel comfortable. I can understand another perspective.
The most important thing I gained is the distinction between good and evil.
This is quite true. Now we happen to have our advantage, fighting the Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: How do you feel about the international alliance?
Do we even know if the Morganas are evil?
I still don't know why you read so much all the time.

Fields.DialogueText: It's amazing how we all gather together, supporting one another. I feel like one of the musicians of Bremen - combined forces to defeat the Morganas.
If they're after us, they want to destroy us, then that's evil. They don't have political motives. They just want destruction and chaos.
I read plenty because it inspires the way I think about the world. The same way some people read the news, I read stories.
I understand you better every day, Theodor Riedel.
Good thing it looks like you'll have me around for a long time.
You're right. This war is far from over.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
I just realized something interesting. Don't laugh when I tell you.
What's that, Theodor?
The Musicians of Bremen -
Oh, not this again.
You said you wouldn't laugh!

Fields.MenuText: I didn't say I wouldn't complain.
Well, I didn't laugh, did I?
Sorry, Theodor Riedel, continue.

Fields.DialogueText: No complaining either. This is important to me.
Complaining and being annoying is just as bad!
Don't interrupt me, Kapitän!
Now, where was I. Oh, right, The Musicians of Bremen.
Your favorite story. About the cat and the dog and the horse and the chicken.
Actually, it was a donkey and a rooster, but that doesn't matter. We're kind of like them. Each of us, fitted for battle, getting ready.
We're all working to make the one goal together. Isn't that right?
That's right. We're going to play our music to the key of BOOM.
I can't wait!
We're all different animals: I'm from Germany, the navigator is from England, the engineer is French.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Well, this is the end of the trail.
But that doesn't mean it's all over.
Well, that is true. I'm just glad we made it out in one piece. We could have been turned into stew!
Now, let's not get ahead of ourselves. It was just a children's story.
Oh, Kapitän. Don't you know by now that nothing is ever "just a story" anymore?
This adventure is going to stay with us for a long time.
I'm tired of hinging on old adventures.

Fields.MenuText: What do you say we have a new adventure?
Let's go find a new mission.
I think it's time to take a break for a little while.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm ready for the next part of our story, Kapitän!
Those Morganas better be ready. We're a force to be reckoned with.
I agree. All this fighting can wait. Just some peace before the storm hits.
So, how about you read me a story from that book of yours?
Which book? Grimm's?
I want to hear your stories. The ones you wrote.
Sure! So...
"Once upon a time, on an ordinary vessel, two friends sailed the seven seas in search for adventure..."
I'm liking it already.
